author: jp.the4ducks0231
content: how easy it would be to list  all the Smart Contracts available on the EVM?

author: jiekai9348
content: You mean all the contracts created all the way back to the first block?

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: It's not difficult, you can fork geth and iterate over a snapshot to dump out all addresses that contain code

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: It's just ~20-30GB of data

author: ogenev
content:
Hey folks, I will not be able to join the west standup call today, my apologies.
 My updates:
- working on overlay protocol implementation in Trin(https://github.com/ethereum/trin). PR is ready for review and addressed some of the comments.
- next, we need to implement network specific event handlers and refactor the json-rpc handlers too, so we can serve state and history overlay networks.

author: pipermerriam
content: Nothing dumb about this.  Analyzing existing contracts is a regular part of figuring out EVM changes

author: newweiv
content: For anyone looking to learn more about the network layer of Ethereum, the official spec is probably the best place to start: https://github.com/ethereum/devp2p. It gives a great technical spec but imo lacks a bit on the design rationale and linking everything together. maybe makes a lot more sense if you have a networking background/are familiar with kademlia. I try to address some of those issues in my (half-baked) devp2p guidebook: https://rebel-bronze-539.notion.site/The-Devp2p-Guidebook-WIP-17f5805c9efc46edadc39f2b5a316d7a.
